header_summary: Discussions on the bitcoin-dev mailing list highlight vulnerabilities in blind MuSig schemes and propose alternative solutions. The importance of consensus change primitives, such as taproot, is emphasized, along with the need for thorough testing and collaboration. Topics also include Lightning Network operations, covenant proposals, Bitcoin Script, and ongoing development efforts. The Lightning Network Daemon (LND) app integration and testing methods, data collection on the Lightning Network, and mitigation strategies for routing and on-chain fees are also discussed.

recent_posts.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
recent_posts.summary: 1. The discussion focuses on vulnerabilities in blind MuSig schemes, particularly MuSig1, and potential solutions.2. Participants discuss the risk of attacks like "Wagner" and propose implementing R commitments in the third round.3. @Jonas suggests an alternative scheme to address vulnerabilities, emphasizing the need for further research.

recent_posts.title: On the experiment of the Bitcoin Contracting Primitives WG and marking this community process "up for grabs"
recent_posts.summary: 1. Antoine Riard emphasizes the importance of consensus change primitives and thorough testing for proposed changes.2. He highlights the significance of Lightning Network development for Bitcoin's survival and his intention to focus on it.3. Antoine invites individuals with proof-of-work and resources to contribute to consensus changes and mentions support from R&D non-profits and venture capital firms.

recent_posts.title: Denial of Service using Package Relay
recent_posts.summary: 1. A user expressed concerns about the safety of accepting unconfirmed inputs in coinjoin transactions.2. The user suggested that coordinators should not accept unconfirmed UTXOs and discussed potential risks.3. The user highlighted the potential benefits of package relay and upcoming RBF proposals for coinjoins.

recent_posts.title: Standardisation of an unstructured taproot annex
recent_posts.summary: 1. The annex feature in Bitcoin's time-locked vault applications can provide powerful benefits, especially for covenants.2. Annex data is not included in transaction IDs, making it a safer way to back up signatures.3. Implementing the annex can help prevent loss of funds and enable more advanced covenants like time-locked vaults.

recent_posts.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
recent_posts.summary: 1. Front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace discussed, potential issue but indicates active participants and liquidity.2. CivKit architecture aims to create a censorship-resistant global trading system while addressing front-running concerns.3. Authors welcome feedback and collaboration with the community for standardizing libraries and ensuring interoperability.

recent_posts.title: Some Day Peg: A crazy two-way peg bridging BTC to other chains Raw
recent_posts.summary: 1. Robin has implemented a two-way peg in Bitcoin Script, allowing asset transfer between blockchains.2. The GitHub gist contains code for depositing and withdrawing funds using OP_RETURN and OP_CHECKMULTISIGVERIFY operations.3. This implementation showcases the potential of Bitcoin Script for creating complex smart contracts and blockchain interoperability.

recent_posts.title: LN Summit 2023 Notes
recent_posts.summary: 1. The conversation covered various aspects of the Lightning Network protocol, including V3 transactions and Taproot upgrade.2. Different versions of the Gossip protocol were compared, favoring Gossip 1.5 for its amount binding feature.3. Approaches for achieving multi-sig channel parties and mitigating channel jamming were explored.

recent_posts.title: option_simple_close for "unfailable" closing
recent_posts.summary: 1. Pull request introduces new protocol for closing channels in Lightning Network, simplifying the process.2. Changes include details on closing initiation, negotiation, and requirements for sender and receiver.3. Older protocols for channel closure removed; added feature option for simplified closing negotiation.

recent_posts.title: Potential vulnerability in Lightning backends: BOLT-11 "payment hash" does not commit to payment!
recent_posts.summary: 1. LND does support paying invoices it generates, but it still finds a circular route through the network.2. Setting up trusted channels allows for paying invoices without going through the actual network route.3. No Lightning node currently has the ability for self-payment, which could be beneficial for custodial service providers.

recent_posts.title: An Open Source Framework to Collect Lightning Network Metrics
recent_posts.summary: 1. Vincent's side project involves collecting data on the Lightning Network to track its evolution and support research.2. The project aims to evaluate proposals and ideas by sharing information among individuals.3. Vincent has created an experimental explorer and a public Graphql API for studying the Lightning Network.

recent_posts.title: HTLC Endorsement for Jamming Mitigation
recent_posts.summary: 1. Participants discuss potential damage from routing and on-chain fees, propose different thresholds for routing fees.2. Reputation-based and monetary-based mitigation strategies explored, with diverging opinions on reliance solely on reputation.3. Challenges of mitigating DDoS attacks in the Lightning Network context highlighted, need for rigorous analysis emphasized.

recent_posts.title: Computing Blinding Factors in a PTLC and Trampoline World
recent_posts.summary: 1. Bastien and ZmnSCPxj discuss a proposal for a schnorr multi-hop locks mechanism in their conversation.2. ZmnSCPxj argues that their proposal is a restatement of the same scheme specified in a previous proposal.3. ZmnSCPxj's proposal simplifies the process by eliminating the need to send left and right locks when using a trampoline node.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core maintainers and communication on merge decisions
active_posts.summary: 1. Discussion on Bitcoin development mailing list raises concerns about decision-making power of current maintainers.2. Bitcoin Core should function as a volunteer project, not controlled by a select few.3. Confusion between Bitcoin Core and bitcoin protocol emphasizes the need for clear governance structures.

active_posts.title: [Mempool spam] Should we as developers reject non-standard Taproot transactions from full nodes?
active_posts.summary: 1. Weiji proposes OP_ZKP opcode for zero-knowledge proof payments, seeking feedback and solutions for L2.2. Erik advises focusing on L2 development rather than implementing new measures at this stage.3. Participants discuss high transaction fees, suggesting filters, censorship, and pruning options to combat spam.

active_posts.title: Package Relay Proposal
active_posts.summary: 1. The submitpackage RPC is available on regtest, but no plans for deploying it on mainnet.2. Lack of recent discussion or timeline for implementing the submitpackage RPC on mainnet.3. Tom is seeking information about the deployment of submitpackage RPC on mainnet.

active_posts.title: Merkleize All The Things
active_posts.summary: 1. Johan asks Salvatore for an on-chain example of a simple game encoded in Bitcoin script.2. Billy Tetrud discusses the potential of Verkle trees but highlights their lack of quantum-safety.3. Salvatore explains the concept of a universal state channel for entering contracts entirely inside the channel.

active_posts.title: Ark: An Alternative Privacy-preserving Second Layer Solution
active_posts.summary: 1. Ark is a new protocol that allows users to send and receive funds without liquidity constraints.2. The protocol uses virtual UTXOs (vTXOs) that live off-chain and must be spent within four weeks.3. Ark's anonymous, off-chain payments are enabled through an intermediary called the Ark Service Provider (ASP).

active_posts.title: New transaction policies (nVersion=3) for contracting protocols
active_posts.summary: 1. Gloria Zhao proposes new mempool/transaction relay policies to aid L2/contract protocols and solve Rule 3 pinning.2. The proposal includes additional rules for V3 transactions and modifications to package RBF rules.3. The new policy aims to provide flexibility, easier fee-bumping, and reduce the need for managing a large UTXO pool.

active_posts.title: A Note on Public Communication
active_posts.summary: 1. Niftynei emphasizes the importance of public communication for technical decisions in the lightning community.2. Public communication helps document options considered and encourages new participants to contribute.3. Vincent agrees that communication has become more fragmented, highlighting the need for improved transparency.

active_posts.title: Proposal: Bundled payments
active_posts.summary: 1. Proposal to extend BOLT-11 includes bundled payments to address prepayment challenges for lightning service providers.2. Bundled payments protect against mining fee attacks and enable non-custodian services.3. ThomasV advocates for implementing bundled payments in BOLT-11 to level the playing field for lightning service providers.

active_posts.title: Resizing Lightning Channels Off-Chain With Hierarchical Channels
active_posts.summary: 1. The Lightning Network proposes routing payments through logical channels owned by specific parties.2. Hierarchical channels may allow for off-chain rebalancing and increased routing fees.3. Despite complexity, active HTLCs funded by active HTLCs could be a valuable idea worth exploring.

active_posts.title: A new Bitcoin implementation integrated with Core Lightning
active_posts.summary: 1. CLN implementation in C-lightning allows for decoupling from block source, focusing on data processing.2. Vincent's plugin supports experimentation with Bitcoin Core alternatives and BIP 157 with Nakamoto.3. Unified fee calculation is crucial for Lightning nodes, but a solution may already exist in Neutrino.

active_posts.title: Liquidity griefing for 0-conf dual-funded txs
active_posts.summary: 1. Liquidity griefing attacks in dual-funded transactions cause locked liquidity to become unusable.2. Proposed solution: never lock UTXOs used in dual-funded transactions to prevent liquidity griefing attacks.3. Implementing a "soft lock" can prevent accidental double-spending and improve protections against liquidity griefing.

active_posts.title: Spending `to_local` output of commitment
active_posts.summary: 1. The writer is questioning the witness script needed for redeeming `to_local` funds in Bitcoin's Lightning Network.2. They are unsure about the transaction required for force closures and seek guidance on generating it.3. The post includes specific details of a committed transaction on a local simnet bitcoin blockchain.
